description:
Chicken calicivirus, also known as avian calicivirus or fowl calicivirus, is a member of the Caliciviridae family of viruses. It is a non-enveloped, positive-sense, single-stranded RNA virus that primarily infects chickens and other domestic fowl.

The virus particle is small, approximately 27-40 nanometers in diameter, and has a characteristic cup-shaped surface structure that is characteristic of the Caliciviridae family. The viral genome is approximately 7.5-8.3 kilobases in length and encodes several key structural and non-structural proteins essential for viral replication and assembly.

Chicken calicivirus can cause a range of clinical symptoms in infected birds, including respiratory distress, diarrhea, reduced egg production, and in some cases, mortality. The virus is primarily transmitted through direct contact with infected birds or contaminated fomites, such as equipment or feed. Proper biosecurity measures and effective vaccination strategies are essential for controlling the spread of this virus in poultry production facilities.

Research on chicken calicivirus continues to expand our understanding of its epidemiology, pathogenesis, and potential zoonotic implications, contributing to the development of more effective prevention and control strategies for this important avian pathogen.
